description.narrative: In the rugged hills of the Black Sea coast of Turkey, hazelnut production is still mostly manual and heavily reliant on seasonal hired labor. Each year, the start of the summer harvest (August to mid-September) is signaled by the arrival of hundreds of thousands of migrant workers and their families—including up to 200,000 children—who help harvest 75 percent of the global hazelnut crop.Most families are internal migrants from the poverty-stricken southeast region of Turkey, near the border with Syria. During the harvest, these workers typically live in temporary tent settlements (sometimes without even clean water). Due to these poor conditions and their economic situation, parents are often left with little choice but to bring their children to the farms. With the uneven terrain of these farms making mechanized production difficult, children are routinely tasked with carrying heavy loads up and down steep hillsides in blistering hot weather. In some areas, more than 40 percent of workers are aged 15-18, and up to 10 percent are even younger.To address child labor and poor living and working conditions in these hazelnut villages, Rainforest Alliance is working with local authorities, companies, and civil society in the region. The project centers around establishing village committees that will take an active role in preventing and remediating child labor and improving the overall wellbeing and livelihoods of farmers and workers. These committees will be made up of a wide range of local leaders and authorities, including kaymakams (district governors), mukhtars (village representatives), representatives from community health and education centers, labor contractors, NGOs. Local leaders are trained on labor rights and effective strategies for addressing the root causes of issues in this region. This project is being carried out by Rainforest Alliance together with Intersnack, Durak Findik, and Balsu.
